sn35.246:1.1: The same five defilements are listed at MN 151:3.3.
sn35.246:1.2: “Sorry state” duhitika is from Sanskrit durhita (Rig Veda 8.19.26; Atharva Veda 4.36.9).
sn35.246:3.3: The ghaṭā (“pot”) is the prominent hump of a zebu bull, which is grabbed to this day by bull wranglers.
sn35.246:3.14: For “straightened up”, accept MS reading udujita, resolved as ud + √uj + ita.
sn35.246:4.1: The “arched harp” (vīṇa) was a multi-stringed instrument held in the lap, whose form is clear from representations in ancient Indian sculptures in Bharhut, Amarāvatī, and Pawāyā, as well as the coins of Samudragupta. The strings, typically seven in number, were attached to the base of the soundbox and passed through holes in the parchment resonator to be tied with cords to the curved neck. It accompanied song or dance, and was played equally by men and women. It is not the modern Indian instrument called veena, which is a lute or stick zither, but rather is similar to the Burmese saung.
sn35.246:4.17: Most of these were established by Ananda K. Coomaraswamy, “The Parts of a Vīnā”, Journal of the American Oriental Society, Vol. 50 (1930), pp. 244–253. “Soundbox” is doṇi (“tub”); “leather resonator” is camma, a piece of leather stretched over the soundbox to enhance the resonance; “neck” is daṇḍa, the curved arm or frame to which the strings were attached; “strings” is tantiyo; and “plectrum” is koṇa. The remaining part is variously spelled as upaviṇe, upadhiraṇe, upadhāraṇe, or upaveṇaṁ, suggesting an early corruption. The preponderance of plural forms nonetheless supports Coomaraswamy’s revised understanding (“The Parts of a Vīṇā”, JAOS, Vol. 57, No. 1 (March 1937), pp. 101–103) that this is Sanskrit upavīṇa, upavāṇa, or upaveṇa having the sense “bindings”. This would be the “tuning cords” by which the strings are tied to the neck and which also serve for tuning.
sn35.246:4.18: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.9 says you can only catch the sound of a harp by getting hold of the lute or player, using this as a metaphor for the search for the Self. DN 23:19.3 tells a similar parable, only with a horn. The Upaniṣad has both instruments.
sn35.246:4.24: The rare verb samanvesati is used in SN 4.23:10.4 and SN 22.87:11.5 of Māra “searching” for the consciousness of a deceased arahant.
